title: Re: Rise of the traid , re-created soundtracks
content: Very tasty! ROTT has one of the greatest game soundtracks I've ever heard, right up there with Tyrian and Death Rally. It's excellent to see someone finally remaking them. I eagerly await more, especially Run Like Smeg.

title: Re: Rise of the traid , re-created soundtracks
content:
Kind of interesting that Lee Jackson said the ROTT songs were some of his less impressive music (too simplistic I think he described them as.) They're still some of my favourites too.

And that's not a bad version of the song either. It would be nice to hear a remix though, instead of just the original with different instruments (hint, hint!)

title: Re: Rise of the traid , re-created soundtracks
content:
Good job. Nice mix too.

I think I'm something of a rarity here, but I prefer covers of video game music to remixes, so it's cool to see another. I don't care about exact adherence to the original song; what I like is to hear guitar parts played for real, and so on. I'd like to do e1m1 from Doom myself, but I can't even make sense of the quick parts yet.________________

title: Re: Rise of the traid , re-created soundtracks
content: Perhaps the domain the songs are uploaded to doesn't accept files with an 'mp3' extension. In this case, it would seem that renaming the extension to .99 is all that's required to bypass that rule.

title: Honest criticism.
content:
That's a nice rendition of Run Like Smeg, yet there are some things that keep me from accepting it as a complete remake.

The percussion is too soft--the sharpness of the cymbal and claps throughout the MIDI help make the tune work.

The chords in the background (what's the term for a fast succession of morphing chords?) sound trippy, but get drowned out by the rest of the song, and don't seem to fit the rhythm in some places. The harmony tracks blend in too well also.

They lose the tranciness that makes this song so classy... I can't really explain why, but you should be able to notice just by listening. I think it's to do with not having a clean enough space between them.

It sounds like there are two overlapping tracks for this part of the song in the MIDI, with slightly different pitches, but I don't recall from when I was perusing the file a couple of months ago.

It also doesn't feel like the chords are flowing right... in the MIDI they go up and down in a similar fashion to the bassline, whereas in your rendition the chord pattern sounds somehow shallow. Listening to it carefully, I think you're cutting some notes short.

Speaking of the bassline, it's too... relaxed. The MIDI sounds almost cheerful, energetic. This MP3 sounds like it's laying back in a bean bag half asleep. The slap nature of the instrument is probably at fault here.

The lead is too soft and echoy. You'd be better off with something that sounds more like a guitar. "Nice" virtual instruments are overrated. These songs don't need realism--that's the magic of electronica.

Nonetheless, noble effort thus far. It's great to see someone tackling these wonderful songs.

What software are you using to construct these?

title: Re: Honest criticism.
content:
I understand, if you wounder whay so many issues has happend thats normally dosnt do, its beacuse of the technical
I know about the bass guitar, but like for that, it whas to many notes for ( virtual bassist, only compatible whit notes from C5 - B5 ), so i need to use another bass guitar, so i select Slap bass, but indeed, it sosnt sound so slappy, and that Airhorn (M1 Korg ) whas not in sync in real-time mode, i had to push it one step forward before the tempo beat and render it, then it whas in synch, so its refused to play synched in real time, but allways it whas 1 beat delayed
That moog chord lead, i dont whay, i have no idea whay it sounds like that

Anyway i ganna take a closer look

title: Re: Honest criticism.
content:
Perhaps the chords sound strange because they're arpeggiated rather the the simple vamp of the original.

Is that bass thing the same reason that Oww! doesn't have the cool 8-1-8-5-1-8-1-5 (in scale degrees) bassline? Cos that's the one thing I really miss, out of all these tunes.________________

title: Re: Rise of the traid , re-created soundtracks
content: There are better ways of ensuring that media files don't autoload in the browser that don't involve renaming files - all they need is a file or two on the web server. [url=http://elouai.com/force-download.php]This[/url] is a good example.

title: Re: Rise of the traid , re-created soundtracks
content:
I've always been of the opinion that you shouldn't force the user to do things your way - what if someone *wants* to autoload MP3s? If they're renamed to .99 then they can't. The best way of doing stuff like this is to present it accurately (i.e. .MP3) and then the user can choose whether they want to autoload the file or not. If it autoloads and they don't want it to, it's their fault for not configuring their browser properly (and once they *do* configure it correctly, it will behave the way they wanted on all correctly designed websites.)

This sort of thing especially annoys me when web designers use Javascript to force things to open in new windows - if I wanted it to open in a new window I'd shift+click the link. Most of the time I don't. Let me browse your website the way *I* want to, don't try to second guess me.

Hmm...got a bit off topic there [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: Re: Rise of the traid , re-created soundtracks
content:
OT as well, but I'm with Malvin on this. If I want to download a file I'll either configure my browser to do that or I'll right click -> save as. Don't make it difficult for me. Unless you're trying to prevent people from using up your bandwidth by playing in the browser every time (in which case Grafix's solution or simply asking us not to would be great), just let things work as they ought to.________________
